christian.overview: The Persian Div (Daeva) underwent religious inversion - from Vedic gods to Zoroastrian demons. This demonization parallels and likely influenced biblical demonology.

biblicalParallels.description: Hebrew shedim (demons) parallel daevas as false gods demanding illicit worship.
Paul's teaching that pagan sacrifices are offered to demons reflects similar conceptual frameworks.
Satan disguising himself as an angel of light parallels daevas' divine origins before revelation of evil.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers were aware of Persian dualism and drew on it while distinguishing Christian teaching.

sources.author: Augustine of Hippo
sources.interpretation: Discussed the relationship between Greek daimones and biblical demons.

historicalConnection.persianInfluence: Jewish exposure to Persian religion during exile influenced Jewish angelology and demonology.
historicalConnection.linguisticLink: Greek daimon and Persian daeva share Indo-European roots with Sanskrit deva (god).

christian.theologicalDistinction: Unlike Zoroastrian dualism, Christianity teaches Satan and demons are created beings subject to divine sovereignty.
christian.typologicalReading: The Zoroastrian hope for Frashokereti when daevas will be destroyed parallels Christian eschatology.
